Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:Sammy wanted to go to where the people were.  Where might he go? Choices:  A: race track B: populated areas C: the desert D: apartment E: roadblock<n><n>### Response:		<n>    - E<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:What home entertainment equipment requires cable? Choices:  A: radio shack B: substation C: cabinet D: television E: desk<n><n>### Response:		Which of the following words would be appropriate to fill in the blank in a sentence? Choices: B: cabinet television A: substation radio shack B: desk cable C: cabinet E: television radio shack B: cabinet television A TV.<n><n>### Explain:<n>Cabinet television is incorrect because it is not entertainment equipment. Substations are not home entertainment equipment. It also uses substation instead of station to describe the same place.<n><n>### Source:<n><img src="https://github.com/dvarghase/Math/blob/master/images/practice-questions/practice-7th-grade-math-problems/practice-geometry-questions/7th-grade-games-practice-test-questions/mixed-subjects.png" alt="Ask a Math Question" style="zoom:50%;" /><n><n><img src="./images/practice_problem_solution_1.png" alt="Demonstrate Your Answer"/><n><img src="images/practiceproblemanswer2.png" alt="Answer to Practice Problem"/><n><img src=".images/practice2.png" alt="" style="zoom: 50%" /><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:Where is a business restaurant likely to be located? Choices:  A: town B: at hotel C: mall D: business sector E: yellow pages<n><n>### Response:		A: (only if given that the restaurant is business oriented and not located in the residential area.)<n><n>### Input (1 or more):Write a program that allows a user to enter a date, 2 other dates, and the month of birth. Determine if the person’s age is under 21 or the age of the person (in years).<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Input: Age: 27 Birthday: 8/14/1978 Date: 4/30/2011
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:James was cooling off two quickly.  He would die if he didn't find some way to stop what? Choices:  A: loss of heat B: revenge C: expansion D: relaxation E: calm down<n><n>### Response:		<n>```B<n>```<n><n>### Input<n>```C<n>```<n><n>## Testing Solution<n>```C<n>int main() {<n>    scanf("%d", &test_cases);<n>    for (int i = 0; i < test_cases; i++) {<n>        test_cases++;<n>        int cases_num = 0;<n>        printf("Case #%d: ", i + 1);<n>        int T = 5;//case 0<n>        do <n>        {<n>            char c;<n>            scanf("%d",&c);<n>            switch(c)<n>            {<n>                case 'A':<n>                    printf("4.5");<n>                    break;<n>                case 'B':<n>                    printf("%d pounds", 6);<n>                    break;    <n>                case 'C':<n>                case 'D':<n>                    printf("@T");<n>                    break ;<n>                case 'E':<n>                    printf(6);<n>                    T+=1;<n>                    break;  <n>                case '0':<n>                    cases_num = 5;<n>                    printf("1 case\nTotal Cases : %d\n",T);<n>                    return 0;<n>                }<n>        }while(c!= '0');<n>        printf("%d cases\nTotal Cases: %d\n", cases_num, T);<n>    }<n>    printf("passed\n");<n>    return 0; <n>}<n>```<n>

How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. Choices:  A: hospital B: head C: sick person D: elderly person E: doctor's office<n><n>### Response:		<n>A correct response includes an explanation worded as follows:<n><n>Sick people typically contract illness because they are weak.<n><n>### Input<n><n>### Response<n><n>### Input

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:What would a camper need to do before he or she can start cooking food? Choices:  A: make breakfast B: go hiking C: pack or bag D: light fire E: grab a match<n><n>### Response:		D A camper has to light the match to make fire.<n><n>### Input What is 3 times as many?<n>Answer: 188<n><n>### Input<n>We have 48 chocolates and a 7th person arrives we should give it to him<n><n>### Response<n>The response is incorrect because we must give 1/7 =12 chocolates to the last guest<n><n>### Input If she has 1/6th of a pound and the package is 17 pounds, how much does she have left?<n>Answer: 360 grams<n><n>### Input There are 50 people in a building. 60% of them are women and 40% are men. How many women are there?<n>Answer: 450<n><n>### Input The next line is a sentence with an unfortunate typo. Correct the typo and write the sentence correctly.<n><n>### Response <n>The response is incorrect<n><n>### Input 15.8 ounces in a pound. Therefore, 4 ounces is how many percent of a pound?<n>Answer: 02<n><n>### Input You walk 1 mile down the street and then turn around. You continue walking and total 1.25 miles. How far did you walk?<n>Answer: 8/10 mile<n><n>### Input Marni has 50 ounces of pills in a medication bottle. She took 1/16th of the pills a day. How many days did she take the pills?<n><n>### Response The response is incorrect because 50 ounes of pilss in a medication bottles divided by 1/16 of them. We have 50 ounese as our answer. <n><n>### Input Tia has twice as much money as Tom. Tia has 104 fewer dollars than Mary. How many dollars have Mary and Tom?<n><n>### Answer The answer needs to be:546<n><n>### Instructions: Answer the question correctly.<n><n>## 2X9 =18<n>##3X7 =21<n>##3X10 =30<n>##6X3 =18<n>##2X5 =10<n>##2X6 =12<n>##

Choices:  A: alabama B: tennessee C: violin case D: music store E: bow and strings<n><n>### Response:		E (music store)<n>The fiddle is from fiddle music and fiddle music originated in Ireland. <n><n>### Instructions:For this task, assume that there is a total of 88,901 bills. <n><n>## Solution<n><n>- 72,022<n><n>The following table contains the values and calculations in the solution:<n><n>```<n>1) 4.5 gallon + 4.5 gallonn + 4.5 galloon + 10.5 gallon = 19 gallon<n><n>6 gallon + 4 + 2 + 2gallon + 3 - 4 -5 <9 => 12<n>3)3 x 2 = 6<n>3 =1<n>1 =1<n><n>4)67<n>13 - 3 -6 => 6<n>5)67<n>```<n>

How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:What's it called when you have seen something through an eyepiece? Choices:  A: sights B: optical illusion C: optical telescope D: light microscope E: binocular<n><n>### Response:		optical telescope<n><n>### Explanation:<n>When you have seen something<n>you put it through an eyepice<n>and thats why its called an optical telescope<n><n>#Explaneation is not necessary if the response is correct<n>### Code:<n>C(1=A,2=B,3=C,4=D,5=E)<n><n>#Explanation must be in a separate line<n>### Example:<n>Explanation:<n>1. I need to clean my house for my mother's dinner.<n>2. I need to prepare a dessert.<n>3. I need to buy the ingredients to prepare the dessert.<n><n>### Input : Write a function that gets the number of inputs. Write a second function that adds all the arguments that the first function received.<n><n>### Response : Add 6 to the function that gets the number inputs and then add all the arguments that the function received<n><n>### Explaneation : If you don't need explanation your explanation won't be required<n>### If your explanation is optional<n>### Above this block of code and below that block of code is explanation<n>### Example of optional explanation<n>### Explanations:<n>### Inputs:<n>function f(x) return x + 1<n>function g(x) return x *1<n>function h(x) return x - 2<n>### Results:<n>f 5 10<n>g 125<n>h -3<n>### <n>###<n>###<n>##<n>###<n>## Example of explanations:<n>###<n>## #<n>### Example:Explaneaton of code:<n><n>#This function adds <n>#six<n>#to the<n>#function that gets the number of times it gets called<n>#and then adds all the arguments passed to it.<n><n>###<n>## If the code is not needed then explanation is also not needed<n>###<n>## Function 1:<n>###<n>function f(x,y) <n>local add, multiply, subtract, div<n>local result = x + y <n>return result<n>###<n>function g(a) <n>local add<n>local multipy = 5<n>local subtract = 0<n>local div = 100<n>local result = multipy * add * subtract<n>return result<n><n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:John loved competing because he was very competitive.  He liked being about to divide people into what categories? Choices:  A: winners and losers B: perform better C: might win D: losses E: enemies<n><n>### Response:		What are choices B,C, and D answers to: John liked to what?<n><n>### Description:Use the information, such as the example to the left to answer the first question.<n><n>## Solution<n>```R<n>n<-rbind(c(5, 4), c(3, 4))  <n>m<-rbind(c(-3, 7), c(3,4,-2)) <n>d<-rbind(c(/4,/6), c(-5,/5))  <n>mat<-rbind(n,m,d)<n><n>result<-matrix(10,-1,3)  <n>result[mat, ]  <n>```<n><n>    [2] 3  0  0<n>    [3] 0  0  3<n>    [4] 0  0 -2<n><n>## Solution<n>![solution](../assets/solution.png)<n>

Our 15 year old daughter is devastated. She can’t go to college if we take the profits and move to a cheaper area. Can you believe that the law allows her nothing?<n><n>#### What should you do?<n><n>I have been trying to get the police to come and put a stop to this. I live 20 miles away but I can’t visit because he won’t allow me in the house to pack up my stuff. If I have to go to jail, so be it. A house in jail is better than no house where I live now. I have already called the police but they tell me I don’t have any proof of anything.<n><n>You can just say you are sorry that you are not going to be living next door to us, and say something nice about your new home. My husband will not even acknowledge the fact that I deserve my belongings. He will only be leaving in a month and I know that the police will never do anything to him.<n><n>#### What might happen when I do nothing?<n><n>When my daughter tells her friends that mommy got thrown out of her house in a box, I know that I will be ostracized from every group that I ever belonged to. I have already put some of my things in boxes before him so I can get some idea of the space I have to put my belongings together for a month.<n><n>If you have any other ideas of something I can do to show my husband that he cannot ignore me and my daughter, please let me know. I just want to be able to spend time alone with my daughter to help her understand what has happened and see how to deal with it. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:What enables most people to transport themselves? Choices:  A: helicopter B: own cars C: speak words D: believe in god E: dance together<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>Input:<n>What enables most people  A: To transport themselves B: to do C: all the above <n><n><n>

The clerk gave her a 40% discount on all yarn. She also bought 4 needles for $1.25. Which is the total cost for the needles and yarn?<n>The correct choice is $21.25.<n>The incorrect choices are as follow:<n><n>1. 150%<n>2. 5 cents<n>3. $22.75<n><n>## Input:A man, a boy, and a dog are standing on the shore and one of them is fishing. There is a boat on the water 100 yards away. The three travelers must cross the water to get to the boat. The man can swim 1 mile per hour, the boy can swim 2 miles per hour, and the dog can swim at 3 miles per hour. The man can make it to the boat in 5 hours. How long will it take for the dog to make the trip alone?<n>Answers will vary.<n>The wrong choice is 40 hours.<n><n>## Input:"What is one number times another and then divided by twice a third number?"<n><n>## Response:<n> 8.0 / 3.0<n><n>### Instances:Answer the following multiplechoice question.<n><n>Input: 0.059<n><n>Input:4.036<n><n>Input:10.554<n><n>## Input:10<n><n>## Input: The answer is 18<n><n>## Input: What is 8 times 18<n><n>8 * 18 = 144<n><n>## Input:%<n><n>30% of 60 is 18, 50% of 65 is 32.5, and<n>100 of 60<n>## Input:32 -<n><n>32 +<n>## Input: - -<n><n>## Instance:Answer the following multiple Choice Question.<n><n>## Instance#: - 0.065<n><n>## Instance:#:453.0 - -<n><n>  ##Instructions<n>  ##Input:<n>  ##Demonstration

Is their number of candy  bars equal?<n><n>### Solution :<n>**Mike and Matt have the same number of candy bars,** so their number of candy bars is the same.<n><n>Mike and Matt both own 18 candy bars.<n><n>### Comments : Comments<n>How many  cans of applesauce do Joe and Tom each have?<n><n>### Answer :<n>Joe and Tom have 16 cans of apples, and 4 candy canes each.<n><n>### Answer:<n>4 candy cane are not the only apples, so 2 candy canes are apples.<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. The question will be updated to reflect your response.<n><n>### Do:<n>### Don't:<n><n>### If you encounter a question you can't answer, respond "cannot answer” (no special characters or periods are needed). The question will be updated or removed once enough information is obtained.<n><n>### This question asks the reader to respond to the input.<n>### Please answer with either a number, a word, or a simple phrase.  Be precise and as specific as possible with your responses.<n><n>### Questions will likely deal with math problems, but they may not.<n><n>### Feedback:<n>All responses will be checked and updated during the week.<n>### If you respond "cannot answer", you need to update the question with additional instructions or information.<n><n>### In all cases, it is better to respond and risk inaccurately than to not respond. If you want to check your work to make sure it is correct, or want to know how exactly how something is supposed to be done, post a comment. This will ask the teacher to provide further feedback.<n><n>### Read and answer carefully.<n><n>### If the answer you want to write is also a multiple-choice answer, click the last choice, then write your answer in the text. This will make your answer more clear and will not cause a problem for the other answers.<n><n>### You may find that some questions are difficult. You may also find that some are very easy. Keep trying until you get at least one right every time.

(Enter your solution as an algebraic expression.)<n><n>### Demostration:<n>(x+2)(x+1) = (x+2)x+x+2+1 = x(2X + 1) = X + X + 1 + 1<n><n>### Instructin:Answer the questions below.<n><n>## Instructions:<n><n>### Demo:<n>```<n>4x² - [9x² - 4x - 9 ] = [4x² - 13x] - 4²<n>```<n><n>## Instruciton:Answer the question below<n><n>### Instuction:Answer the following multiple chose question:<n><n>### Answers:<n><n>### How many hours of TV shows were downloaded on 2007 March 25th?<n><n>```<n><n>(1) How many TV shows were downloaded at some time on the 25th? <n><n> (2) How many TV shows had been downloaded by the end of the 25th, midnight?<n><n><n>(3) How many days were there in the month of March?<n><n><n>```

If there are 1/4 as many red chairs as there are blue, how many chairs are in the classroom?<n>Answer:: 12<n><n>### Demopstration:<n><n><n>### How many times does 3 divide 13? Exclude factors and remainders.<n>- 3 divided 13 is 3 with remainder of 4 (4*2=8)<n>- 3 divided by 4=0 <n>- The Remainder is the factor.<n>- 4+ remainder(4) is total (8)<n>- How many time does 3 divide 6 is (2/3)* 6=12/3=4

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. There must be a question to respond to.<n>2. You may not change anything in the original input. ​<n>3. There may be one or more choices. Each choice is an option that can be selected.<n>4. When an option in the choice list is selected by the computer, the choice is recorded under that choice's corresponding choice statement.<n>5. The computer selects the choice, displays the choice statement, and then displays a new input question.​<n>6. All input questions must be completed before any data is saved.<n><n><n>**<n>**This is an example of how the instruction would look in the application for reference. If you are uncertain about the process, refer to the documentation.

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:The policemen wanted to clear the scene of the accident, so what did they do to traffic? Choices:  A: hurry along B: direct traffic C: help D: force open door E: corner thief<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Input - Output Explanation:<n><n>### Solution<n><n>#### Solution One:<n><n>```bash<n>#!/bin/bash<n><n>read -r<n><n>count()<n>{<n>    count=0<n>    for word in $1;<n>    do<n>    number=$(echo $word | wc -w)<n>    count+=($number)<n>    wc -w $1<n>    done<n>}<n>```<n><n>#### Solution Two:<n>```bash<n>#!sh<n><n>echo -e "\n$(tput setaf 2)Input: Janet has more than Brenda.\n$(tput setfa 1)"<n>```<n><n>Answer: <n>```shell<n>#!/bin/sh<n><n>echo -ne " Janet has more than. Brenda:\n"<n><n>arr=($(echo "Janet has more than Brendna.\n" | $SHELL_COMPLETION_CMD))<n><n>for i in "${!arr[@]}"; do<n>	echo "$i"<n>done<n>```<n><n>#### Answer:<n>```bash<n><n># Answer:<n><n>4. Input:"Janet has more than. brenda: "<n><n># Input:<n>5. Janet has more than brenda.<n>```<n><n><n>## Inputs & Outputs<n><n>* ### INPUTS:<n><n>### Examples<n><n>### Exercise:<n><n>```bash <n>#!/bin/ash<n><n>read -r -s -p '\n# Instructions:\ninput  : Janet has more than. Brenda\ninput  : Pete walked 5 block from his house to the garage in Houston\ninput  : In a classroom,, there are three types of chairs: blue, green, and white\ninput  : Traffic has stopped because of the accident\n# output:  <n>echo "$(tput setaf 4)\nHow many cards do they have if Pete has 40 cards\nless.\n$(tput sgr0)"<n><n>```<n>#### ASSIGNMENT<n>```python<n>#!/bin/Python<n><n># The number of white chairs is 16<n># The number of blue chairs is 5<n># The number of green chairs is the product of the number of blue chairs and the number of green chairs

How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:A balloon or two is a staple at a what? Create two columns of text (or if your doc already has columns, then make sure they are aligned to the left).<n>3. The left column will contain the Input. <n>4. Leave 2 blank lines between the input and your explanation.<n>5. Write a complete sentence that explains the result.<n>6. Indicate the type of input in all capitals.<n>7. Write one explanation per line. (This is to make it easier for you to complete your work and for us to score it. <n>    Don't worry if there are no spaces between the input and your answer -- just continue to write in your word processor.)<n>8. Make your final line a conclusion in the form: Therefore,...<n>9. The response must be in your own words, so make sure that you don't copy the responses word for word from anyone else.<n>    There might be a variation of the response (i.e., some other explanation other than the one given or a different approach to the problem) that is also correct, so feel free to present the problem in a novel fashion.<n><n>### Sample Response to Input:<n>Input: Janine is 34, and the average weight for her team of cheerleaders is 101 pounds. 10 cheerleaders weigh less than 110 pounds, and 90 cheerleaders weigth more than 110. We can talk about the students being competent in their course work and doing well (winning) by getting passing grades in the courses. Or, we can talk about the students doing well in their courses and not losing (having a sticker or not) due to bad grades.<n>

(1) how many chairs were originally needed (2) how many were taken (3) how many are remaining.<n>

What time will the two planes be taking off at the same time.<n><n>### Response : C<n>### Explanation<n>The time is set off the same, therefore the times to leave are at the same time<n>### Input : 8.48<n>### Answer : 06/28/2017 06:48:29<n><n>### Answer (2):<n>Given a time span of 65 days. Convert it to a number of days, add 1 day to both the number of days and to the starting time (the starting time is 12:00pm) and then subtract the start time from the end time. In this task the end time is the start time for the next task.<n><n>Input :  `number_of_days = 65` <n>### Explanion <n>`number_of_days` is set to a time span of 39 days <n><n>Input : `time_start = 06/20/2017`<n>### Explanon<n>Time is set off hours and minutes, convert the date to a numeric, add 24 hours to the starting time, and subtract it from the end time which is the start time for task3. The starting time is the end of the workday.<n><n>Input : `start_time = 12:04:00`<n>### Explantion<n>time is set off hours and minues, convert it to a numeric, add a value to the 24 hours of the starting time and subtract it from the ending time.<n>### Explantion<n>```<n>Input : `end_time = 11:00:00`<n>```

Choices:  A: giggle B: lie C: laughing D: chuckle E: smoke<n><n>### Response:		<n>D<n><n>### Explanation:<n>D: Chuckle means to laugh quietly, like a chuckling sound.<n><n>### Input<n>What was the weight per bushel of corn in Illinois for 1939?<n><n>### Response<n>A: 86 lbs<n><n>### Explantion<n>A: A bushel is a dry measure of 8 gallons that is used mainly for food, especially grain products (oatmeal, cornmeal. Ect.) 86 is the lowest known amount of weight that is 1 bushel which is only a little higher than 83. Therefore, 86 pounds per bushel is the correct answer because the question has asked for the minimum amount of weight per bushel.<n><n>### Examples:<n><n>Input: How many chocolates does Nicole have?<n>Answer: 7<n><n>Input: You have the same number of chocolates as Sara. A likely is a probability or a chance of something, so what is the probability that a child may go to play? Let's look at the choices and say why.<n>Choices A and D are all the correct sentences, but they are very different from each other. So there's only one.<n><n>![](instruction40.png)<n><n>I picked D.<n><n>I chose a because it says happiness when it should be sad because it's probably sad while going.<n><n>I chose E because it's probably going to walk quickly but it says walk slowly<n><n>Because I picked A and B is incorrect.<n><n>I don't like this question because it has nothing to do with going to play.<n><n>![](input40.png)

He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:Where would you put a computer other than a desk? Choices:  A: apartment B: table C: school D: office E: house<n><n>### Response:		<n>a)a desk<n>b)an apartment<n>c)a table<n>d)an office<n>e)a house

How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:Where can you find pamphlets regarding diseases and ailments? Choices:  A: theaters B: health department C: library D: drawer E: mail box<n><n>### Response:		The answer is C.<n><n>### Explanation: You might think that pamphlets are found in libraries or theatre lobbies. But they are more widely distributed. You might be able to obtain them in your mailbox if you ask for them directly. A pamphlet is a printed, small booklet that is placed in libraries, schools, doctor's offices and even on theatre walls with information. It is very helpful in learning to understand the information that it contains.<n><n>### Input-output<n>**Input**: What's the definition of a frown?<n>**Output**: A grimace<n><n>**Input**: How many times have you met your favorite movie star?<n>**Output** : Twice<n><n>**Input** : What's the population of Tanzania?<n>**Output** Tanzanian (pronounce dun-zi-yan).<n>

How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:What would a person do to help someone that is not able to speak coherently? Choices:  A: sign language B: complete sentence C: drink tea D: feel angry E: cross street<n><n>### Response:		<n>The process of breaking a complex sentence into smaller components is called paraphrasing. The paraphase needs to be done is done in the order of the sentence. An interrupter should be used for sentences with long clauses. The interrupter is written in brackets with the words omitted in it.<n><n>### Input : Find the greatest number and write it in standard form. If there are 68 cars in a city lot, 7 buses were parked. If 184 students attended the dance, then 28% of them were from another district, and there were 45 more people from the other district than there were at the school. How many people went?<n>#### How did you solve it?<n><n>#### Instruction:Solve the equation below (A=6/7 B-9 C-9 D+2). Answer:<n><n>1. $19 x A=\frac{19}{7}$<n>2. $\frac{9}{9} x A=\frac{9}{7}$<n>3. $\frac32 x B =\frac{3}{1}$<n>4. $A x 9=19$<n>5. $A+B=19A\implies A=6/7$<n><n>### Input::Write an inequality that solves 9 = 3x + 7.<n><n>#### How did you  solve it?<n><n>When one adds or subtracts opposite signs between two addends, the result has no sign at all.<n><n>$\begin{array}{ll}(9-3x)=(7 + 9) \\9-21=7+9 \\ 20 = 16 \\20=16 \\20 = 14 \\ 19=16 \\ 20=14 \\0>2\end{array}$<n><n>### Input  :  $5(3x+y)-4=(3x+4)(y-2) $<n><n>#### How did u solve it?<n><n>$\begin{div}`<n><n>$\begin{align}\text{Expanded form:}&\quad& 5(3x+3y).-\text{four}&&\text{Equals}\\ &\text{Expanded form:&}&\quad&(3x+6y-(4)(3x+3y)&&\text{Equals}\\&\text{Expanded form :

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:What usually happens to people who are models? Choices:  A: very ugly B: appear beautiful C: free slaves D: pay bills E: suffering pain<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>In this case, when people are models, mostly they don’t look ugly, but they have beautiful faces.<n>### Input: What is the opposite of ‘beauty is in the eye of the beholder’? A: A: beauty is in the eye of beheld B: beauty is in the mind of the one who sees C: beauty is in the heart of the beheld one D: beauty is not in the eye of beholder<n><n><n>### Response<n><n>Beauty is always seen in the eye of the person which is looking at someone. To be more accurate, beauty is in the eyes of the beholder.<n>### Input A woman went to college and studied a certain subject. She studied that subject for four years and graduated. What subject it was that she studied?<n>### Response The subject the woman studied was English.<n><n>### Input A person is on her way to work one day in her van. She drives six and a half miles at a constant speed. She drives at a constant speed because she is late for work. She drives at a non-constant speed because she is in the fast lane of traffic on an expressway that she would rather not be in. She drives for a total of 10 minutes and 20 seconds. What is her average speed, rounded to the nearest whole mile per hour (mph)?<n>### Response Her average speed is 55mph.<n><n>### Notes The woman takes the fast lane on an 85mph expressway. She uses the speed of the fast lane as her constant speed. The woman has an average speed of 60 mph when using the fast lane and her average speed is 40 mph when she is not using the fast lane.<n><n>### Hints:<n>When the woman uses the fast line she is driving fast. When the woman is in the fast lined she has a constant rate. When the woman is not in the fast lined, she will be slow on average. When woman is not in the faster then, then she will average faster than 55 mph because the slow lanes will not go as fast with traffic in it and at time it may not be able to go as fast. When her non constant lane is faster the more likely it will be to average for her to be going faster than 55.<n>### Input Which term describes

Print a different message if the user selects NO, and a third message if the user selects YES.<n><n>### Sample Solution<n><n>``` c<n>#include <stdio.h><n><n>/**<n><n> * Prompt a dollar amount, round to the nearest <n><n> *.25 cent,.50 cent, or.75 cent, and return <n><n> * the savings. The numbers that you are asked are decimal numbers and should be rounded appropriately.<n><n>### Evaluation:<n>In the first two problems, you are doing simple division involving a number and a whole number. Choices:  A: south pacific B: sea world C: pacific ocean D: indian ocean E: gulf of mexico<n><n>### Response:		You can view sharks in clear tunnel at south pacific and sea world.<n><n>### CORRECTED INPUT<n><n>118 points.<n><n>### Explanation<n>Input: Where may I view sharks, in a clear tunnel?<n>Answer: You can view sharks, in clear tunnels at South Pacific and SeaWorld.<n><n>### Test Input #1:<n>What do you see when you look into it?<n><n>### Test Answer #1:<n><n>### Test input #2:<n>Is it round?<n><n>###  Test Answer #2:<n><n>### Exercise<n><n>### Input/OutPut:<n>Input: What is the largest city in Florida?<n>Output: The largest city in Florida is Jacksonville.<n><n>### Input #1:<n>How may I apply for a job with the city government?<n><n>### Input#2:<n>I need to apply for a job with city government.<n><n>### Output:<n>You may apply for a job with City Government at City Hall.<n><n>### Solution:<n>Here are some possible solutions, but this solution is not necessarily the only one.<n><n>\begin{code}<n>Input: What is there to do in New York?<n>Output: There are several attractions to do in New York. You can go visit the empire state building, the rockefeller center, Times Square, and the Statue of Liberty.<n><n>Input: Are you from here?<n>Output: No, I am not from here<n><n>Input: How do we get there?<n>Output: I don't know how we will get there. You may want to find that out yourself.<n><n>Input: How can I get there?<n>Output 1: You may take a bus. Or you can take a taxi or ride share service.<n><n>Output 2: You may want to purchase a car or you can rent a car.<n><n>Input: What is available to do when visiting the state or city?<n>Output: You can find several things to do in the city, you may go visit the zoo, the botanical gardens, and you can go to some museums.<n><n>Input: Do you have a job?<n>Output: Yes, I have a job working as a security engineer.<n>\end{code}<n><n>### Exam Practice<n><n>\

A solitary group must be small so that it is not a crowd.

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:A man was driving himself to the airport, where did he put his luggage? Choices:  A: closet B: at hotel C: sidewalk D: bus stop E: trunk<n><n>### Response:		<n>Which answer choice best completes the request?<n><n>A. Choice A, Closet<n><n>Answer choice B (hotel) is wrong. Hotels typically have luggage pickup, and therefore they dont always have a closet either. Answer choice C is too vague. It doesnt give much of a description of where he is so you cannot accurately answer it. The other options may or may not have luggage lockers on site. However, I would be inclined to choose choice A with the closet because the person is driving themselves. Therefore, theyre probably planning on carrying the luggage onto the airplane, and it would be easier to put in a closet then carrying it around with you.<n><n>### Input:"The 1995 total for all federal, state, and local taxation was $2.3 trillion, and the 1995 national consumer price index, measured in 2009 dollars, was 174.3 (Bureau of Economic Analysis, n.d.). What were the total government expenditures and the percent change of expenditures in 2008 in constant dollars from 1995?"<n>### Response: Which 2 calculations would yield the correct answer to this question? (Choose all) A: Total government expenditures / total revenue B: Total government expenditure/ total government revenue C: Total government expenditute/ total government revenue D: Total government expenditudes/ total national income E: Total government expendities/ national income<n><n>### Response<n><n>Because of the nature of the question, the best way to answer it would be to do both A and B. B is essentially the question that shows how much they have over after they paid off their national debt. In A, we are just looking at income and expenses.<n><n>### A man weighed himself. The scale read 105 lb. After he took his shower and drank breakfast, the scale read 108 lb. What percent of the time does the scale understate his weight?<n>### Response<n>This would fall under the category of a percentages question. Therefore, the question is looking for the person to do both parts of the equation. We are first given the initial weight, and then we are asked to determine the remaining weight after all of

How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:What is something you do  in a bank? Choices:  A: make noise B: have tea C: make time D: make payments E: take time<n><n>### Response:		<n>B<n><n>### Reason:<n>In a bank they serve tea to customers.<n><n>### Input :  What is something you don't do in a bank? Choices:  A : make time B : have tea C : take time D : make payments E : make noise<n><n>### Response :<n>B<n><n>## Input:What is something I do in bank? Choice : Answer: Make payments.<n><n>### I need : Make nois at the bank.<n><n>### Response<n><n>### Input <n>Choices are: Make noise, make payments, have tea, take time and make time<n><n>### response <n>### Demonstion:<n>### Input<n>```python<n>>>> what_is_something_i_do_in_a_bank[4]<n>'make noice'<n>```<n>### Answer input<n>```<n>>>> which_one_do_you_need<n>```<n>the program will print 'have tea'.<n><n>### Demostration:<n>### input<n>```python<n>>> from importlib import metadata<n>>> <n>>> import_metadata()<n>```<n><n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:If a human wants to enjoy another human's company, where might they go? Choices:  A: place of work B: office C: friend's house D: workplace E: deep thought<n><n>### Response:		In 425 (425 people go to their place of work to visit the offices of their co-workers), the human-centric place that people visit to engage in person-to-person interactions is a place of work. The other choices are either places where people go to do work that is not directly related to people-to-person interactions (office), a house for friends (friend's house), or another place where people work (workplace).  <n><n>### Input<n>In a country with more than twenty states, the 26th state has about a quarter as many residents as the 12th largest state. The 23rd state has 6% of the residents of the smallest state. If the smallest state has a population that is one twentieth that of the largest state, what percentage of the total population of the country are people whose home state is smaller than the 26th largest state?<n><n>### Response<n>Since this question is not stated using variables, we can use this technique to fill the placeholders: 23<26 which indicates that 26 is the bigger number. We know that 23<23 because the smaller number is the place of the larger number. 6%x26 is.06*26, so we get.144. That puts the number of people who stay in their home state at 16.6%.<n><n>In addition, we know that if x<y, then x<x/y. This holds because if x<y, which means x<y, because if one is smaller than the other, then the bigger one must be bigger than the other. This means that: 23<x=23<26/23 = 5/8 <n><n>So, by plugging 23/26 back into (23<x)=(7/8>x)<n>.144= (7/8)>23/26. Since we know that 144/26=5,.144/.26=5/144 so.144/.193 is.596/193. This gives.29/3 to the right side of the equation.

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:The man uses grooming before a job interview, what is he trying to portray? Choices:  A: mountains countryside B: ground C: bridge D: mountain range E: surface of earth<n><n>### Response:		Choose 2 options from the list and write 2 different sentences that explain why the options are correct.<n>Answer: Option B and E:<n><n><n>### Input(A):<n>A small shop sells only 2 types of coffee — light and dark. If every morning, the shop has 3 light coffee cups and 6 dark coffee cups for sale. How many light coffee cups do they have in their shop?<n><n>### Response (A):<n>1. A shop has 3 light and 6 dark coffee in their shop<n><n>2. When the shop has 3 and 6, there are 9 in all<n><n>**1.** We know that this is a shop that only sells light and dark coffee, for morning, when it has 3 light coffee, there are 6 dark coffee. The shop has 3 light 6 dark, in all, the shop has 9.<n><n>**2.** They use 6 and 3, so 9 in all.<n><n>**2** The shop has three coffees and six coffees the shop has nine in all.<n><n>### Inputs(B):<n>The average number of days that the school bus stops to pick up and drop off children is 12. If the bus stopped twice as often to pick up as to drop off children, how many stops does it make in all?<n><n>### Responses (B):<n><n>1>When the bus stop the pick up is twice as many, there are no drop off on 6 times.<n><n>2>When the bus stops 12 times for pick up 6 times for drop off to pick up and drop up, there are 18 in all.<n><n><n>#### 1:  <n><n>**when the bus stop the pick**, the child go twice as many **to the pick up the bus stop**, the bus stop, when the children from the school to the home.<n><n>When the bus stop  the pick up, the child go twice from the school to the bus stop. When the children go to the school, the bus picks up twice the children.<n><n>### Resources:<n>[https://www.mathplayground.com/20questions.html](https://www.-mathplayground-com-20questions-html)<n><n>### Resources:(A)"How many different ways can you make

On a recent day, 100 people purchased items from the store. The probability of each event is as follows:<n><n> * The first 100 people who enter the store enter at the register. What is the probability of this event?<n> * The next 20 customers, after the initial 100, enter from around the building to the front door. What is the probability?<n> * 15 people enter from the parking lot. Of the 15 people, 3 people go to the cash register. What is the ratio of these two fractions?<n> * 11 customers enter from the cashier to the storage room. What is the probability that they enter from the storage room to the shelves on the floor?<n><n>### Demands:<n><n>### Answer:<n>A-E: Register-Parking Lot-Cashier-Back Stockroom<n><n>### Where do at least 100 people usually enter?<n><n> A-B: Register-Parkings<n><n>### 3<n><n> *The probability that 100 customers will enter at the register<n> * The probability that 103 people from the parking lot will enter<n> * The probability of 11 people from the shelves to the ground.<n><n>#### Choices are all the same<n><n>

Choice E, therefore, is incorrect.<n><n>Choices B, D, C<n><n>### Input : <n><n>Write a program that outputs one or more numbers: "n^2" where n is any positive integer. For example, if you enter "4", the output will be "16".<n><n>### Input 1<n><n>Enter the value of "n": 4<n><n>### Instructions<n><n>Write the function named "n^2" that outputs "n^2" for a given "n".  Use the function "n^2" to calculate your score.<n><n>### Input<n><n>Enter function name: n^2<n><n>### Response<n><n>Write a definition for n^2 as shown below.<n><n>### Exaimation<n><n>The definition: input -> output, should be for a real number or for a function that could accept real numbers. The definition provided only accepts n - a real number.<n><n>### Comments for the Editor<n><n>The name of the function should be "n^2" and not "n^" as stated in the instructions.<n><n>The example above is not in good syntax. <n><n>### Definition :<n><n>```python<n>def n2(n=4) :<n>result = n*n<n>print (result)<n>```<n><n>### Definition<n><n>```python<n> def n2(number):<n>    number = number**2<n>    return number<n>```<n><n>## Comments for the Editor (Input & Output)<n><n>### Input Comments<n>    Expected Input:<n>    ```<n>    <Enter n or a function that takes n as input><n>    ```<n>    n= 4<n><n>## Output comments<n><n>### Output Comments<n>    Exapcted Output:<n>    ```<n>    16<n>    ```<n>(n^2) = output<n><n>### Expected Output (n>= 1)<n><n>    ```<n>    25<n>    ```<n>(1^(

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:What is the hope of playing sports without competition? Choices:  A: running B: have fun C: balls touch D: winning E: get tired<n><n>### Response:		I feel competition is essential to any sport and sport without competition is not complete as it will make it dull and boring.<n><n>### Input What is the most important part of playing sports? Choices: 	 A. play games B. be fair C. make friends D. keep trying E. have fun<n><n>### Response I would say fairplay is the most important part as it is what differentiates between winning and losing in competition.<n><n>###Input What is the reason of playing sports? Choice: A: health & wealth B: make friends C: fun & exercise D: to earn money E: to be healthy<n><n>### Response Playing games is to keep the body healthy with the right amount of exercise to the player.<n><n>###Instruction: Complete the table below. <n><n>### Demostration:  <n>|Number|Factor|Input|Multiply by|Output|<n>|:------------:|:------------:| |:-------------:| |<n>|   1 |  |   |    |<n>|   2 |  |   |  |<n><n>### Input 1: What is the sum of 7 and 2 multiplied by 5?<n><n>### Response The sum of 7 and the variable 2 multiplied by the number 5 is 40.<n><n>### What is the product of 7 and the number 3?<n><n>###  Response The product of 7 and 3 is 21.<n><n>###How is the sum and product related to each other?<n><n>### Answer The sum and product of any number is a linear equation in the second grade as shown on the above table. <n>

If Isabela is 61 inches tall, how tall are Javier and Hector?"<n><n>### Response:"Javier is 21 in tall."<n><n>### Input;What is the sum of the integers in 708916?<n><n>### Response;The sum is 708905.<n><n>### Input";The sum of the integers in the year 2000 is the number of days in that year. The number of months in 2000 has the same number of days as the number of leap days in 2002. If the number of days in 2020 is 366, how many days is a year, starting in 2001, if it has an even number of leap days?"<n><n>### Solution";The sum of the integer in 2008 is 73301."<n><n>### Solution;2007 is 7 days long.<n><n>### Solution2;The year 2007 is odd years.<n><n>###  Input";A sum of eight integers is 81. If six of them are even and the other two are odd, what’s smaller?<n><n>### Solution"14."<n><n>### Problem1;18.<n><n>### Problem2;61.<n><n>### A group of 4 people is chosen from 5 candidates who each have 2 jobs. What is the probability that everyone in the group has a job?<n><n>### Explanation";The group has 4 people, so it cannot get the 4 people. Because everyone in the group has 2 jobs, so it cannot get it."<n><n>### Question";8%."<n><n>### Instructions4.;Multiply the digit number and the digit number<n><n>### Multipliers";223" and"159"<n><n>### Provider";3"*<n><n>### Output";223*3 equals 779."<n><n>###  Integers";(-4)<n><n>### Providers";0" and"-5"<n><n>### Output

Choices: A: everyone B: men C: women D: the king<n><n>#### Response: Complete the sentence by choosing the one option that does not belong in the group.<n><n>### Coding: The following is a basic computer program, which you will be expected to complete.<n><n>### Input and Output:<n><n>Clarisse is 7 years old, and her mother is 37 years old. Clarisse’s mother can explain how to do arithmetic problems involving fractions to Clarisse.<n><n>Fractions represent two numbers and contain four basic parts: the _numerator_ (n), the _denominator_ or _bottom number_ (d), the _fraction_ (i.e., n/d), and the _proper fraction_ (i.e. n/d>0). A denominator with a 1 means that one whole is being split up, for example 1/2 or 1/2=110.<n><n>A _reciprocal_ of a fraction is an operation that reverses the division process. That is, the reciprocal shows you how many times one part of a fraction can be divided into any other part. For example, 1/5 of 10 will be 2. Like a division problem, this problem shows us how many times a whole can split into two parts, for example, 1/2=5, and 1/2=2.<n><n>In the problem below, write the fraction in its simplest form by filling in zeros in the numerator if necessary, and fill in the denominator with the proper number.<n><n>Given numerator, denominator, and/or fraction:<n><n>1. In the first step, convert the fraction into a decimal. For example, 9/13 is converted to 0.6923.<n><n>2. Then compare these two decimal numbers. If the number under the decimal is higher, write that number in the numerator.<n><n>3. Then compare the two numbers now in the numerator. If the other number is a bigger number, fill in zeros in the numerators until they are the same.<n><n>4. If both the numbers in the denominator are the same, the fraction is in its simplest form.<n><n>### Your Task:

How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:When he was a small child he called the giraffe mascot a cow, it was a fond memory of the now defunct what? Write a method that can be passed an object to determine whether it exists in the collection. If it does exist, pass the number of times you found the object. If it does not exist, return true<n><n>### Demostration:The classroom example that can be used here<n><n>### Response<n>the function should be like this:<n><n>### Instutions:<n>```<n>import java.util.*;<n>interface Setter<n>{<n>    void set(Object object);<n>}<n><n>class Collections<n>    {<n>        Collections(Setter objectSet)<n>        {<n>            objects = objectSet;<n>        }<n>        Object[] objects;<n>    }<n>    public static void main (String [] args)<n>    {<n>        // Create a classroom collection with 20 objects:<n>        Collections c = new Collections(new Object() //The classroom collection we are implementing<n>        {<n>            public void set(Object object)<n>            {<n>                // Add this element to the collection<n>                Arrays.add(objects, object);<n>            }<n>        });<n>```<n>### Demostraction:<n>  The implementation of the collection should be like this<n>  ```<n>  class Room<n>  {<n>    Room(){}<n>    public int size(){<n>      int size = 0;<n>      Iterator iterator;<n>      Iterator.forEach(c.getIterator(), object -> size++;<n>      return size;<n>    }<n>  }<n>  class Collection<n>  {<n>    Collection(Setter objectSet) {<n>      objectSet.set(new Object());<n>     ...<n>   }<n>    int size() {<n>      return Collections.size();<n>    }<n>  private final Object[] objects;<n>  }<n>  ```<n><n><n><n>### Instuctions:Write a function called intToRoman that takes one integer as an argument.<n>It is returning a String representing that int value in the Roman numerals<n><n>### Demetstrasion<n><n>```<n>public static String intToRoman(int n)<n>{<n>// TODO: implement me<n>}<n>```<n>### Responce<n>```<n>import java.*;<n>public class intToR

How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:Where can someone view a county highway as a line? Choices:  A: from the sky B: map C: cross counties by car D: country E: michigan<n><n>### Response:		<n>You said, "They can view a county highway as line from the sky." You did NOT say how many. I think you needed to ask, "Where can someone view a _county highway_ as a line?" They can only view a county highway as _one_ line. They could not view the county highway as _many_ lines at once. Choice A is correct.<n><n>

Choices:  A: space shuttle B: detroit C: stairs D: downtown E: elevator<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### A: space shuttles are faster and they do not need the floor but he is human and he will not able to do that and that is not an option. <n><n>### B: stairs but he cannot take the stairs. <n><n>## Demonstration :<n><n>Input: John is a human (you'll know this later). he has a wheelchair due an accident.  He would go to the 3rd floor of his apartment bld (the stairs are only available for the human). <n><n>## Output: (John would not be able to get to the 3rd by the stairs. He will need to take the elevator.)<n><n>Input: How much is 314.56 – 124.98?<n><n>## Response:<n>```JavaScript<n>(new Math()).div(new (new (new ("314.5...")).replace(/\./)), "124.9"))<n>```<n>The method given is the div method of JavaScript. This method accepts two arguments, and it returns a number and one more than what we want. The other thing is the output would be that number and an integer<n>### Output:<n><n>### Demostration:<n><n>### Mathematic:<n><n>### Output Mathemtical:<n><n>### Input :<n>- 20.0 -   5.30<n>- 9.30         - 4.40<n><n>### Output: <n><n>### Response Math:<n><n>### Method:   <n><n>### Demointation:<n><n>## Sample outputs:<n><n>## Output Math:<n><n>```JavaScript<n>(5 - 2.30) / 2<n><n>-3.7 / 2<n><n>0.345 / 2<n><n>1.78 / 2<n><n>```<n><n>## Input: <n>```JavaScript<n>The first floor is the main floor.<n><n>Input: How many floors are there on the building?<n><n>```<n><n>Output: 4. (The floor is 3+1.)<n><n>The floor is 1+ floor. so if you want to calculate the floor in that building you have to add first and then floor.<n><n>## Output:<n><n>```JavaScript

Choices:  A: back pocket B: meeting C: drug store D: home E: school<n><n>### Response:		<n><n><n>### Instructions:Use the following to answer the next 5 questions.<n><n>**1.** You can use the numbers below to represent variables.<n>* Choices are A through G; if you don't select a choice, the answer may be different from what you would expect.<n>* You can use any digits more than once; also, remember the numbers must add up to 100.<n><n>\- Answer: $11$<n><n>**2.** There are 5 people and 4 computers<n><n>\- Answer:`Jill, Mike, Natalie, Sam, Alex, and Nicole<n><n>\- Answer:(7/30) * (5/4)<n><n>\- Answer:$2300<n><n>\- Answer:\- $4*27*2=4*2*2=2$<n><n>\- Answer:"$0$"<n>    <br><n>**3.** In the expression (7/3) + (2+3)=?, the numbers "7, 3, 2, and 3" stand for variables.<n><n>\-  Answer: $16$<n><n>\-  Let "a" represent the first number above, "b" the second, and "c" the third.<n><n>\- Let "d" be the fourth variable number. This means that "d" can take any "variable" number that will bring the total to 100 (the answer).<n><n>\- Answer="7(d - 4b + c) - 2a + 3d + 3 = 16"<n><n>\- Answer= (2a + 3b +4c + 3d +4(d - 4*b + c) +3)/100<n><n>\```math<n> \left ( \text{Sum of each variable} \right )<n>  \text{: }  =\frac 13 45<n>  \text{: }\to\frac 13=11 <n>     \end{array}<n>      \to \begin{array}{c}  \text{Sum of variables } \\  =\frac 1{3} <n>      \text{: }<n>      \\  \to\frac 1{3}\times \frac 13 <n>      \text{ } \\ \hline

How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:What area is likely to contain a large village? Choices:  A: rural area B: big city C: suburbs D: ohio E: countryside<n><n>### Response:		<n>If 1 was the correct option then you need to insert an appropriate paragraph<n><n>If 2 was the correct option then no paragraph necessary  <n>If 3 was the correct option then insert one of the blank options above<n><n>If 4 was the correct then 2 appropriate paragraphs<n><n>If 5 was the correct then 9 appropriate paragraphs<n><n>### Question: If you found a letter lying on the street, but there is no address and it is for someone you do not know, should you return it?<n><n>If 1 was correct then you need to insert one of the blank paragraphs above.<n><n>If 2 then there is nothing to insert since the letter should be kept.<n><n>If 3 then you need to insert the paragraph above.<n>

How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:When a monkey is taken away from their home they are often brought to this place where people wear white coats. Choices:  A: rain forest B: research laboratory C: cage D: treetops E: south africa<n><n>### Response:		A Monkey is brought to a research laboratory<n><n>### Explain your answer: The text prompts you with information about monkeys being brought to research laboratories. We don't know which of these places the monkeys are taken to. The research laboratory is a good bet.<n><n>### Input 2 A research laboratory is a place where scientists study monkeys. Scientists use monkeys for medical and veterinary research to improve the health of people and animals that share the planet with them.<n><n>### Response 2 A research laboratories are places where scientists study monkey. They use animal to improve the health of peoples or anima because of the need to improve the health and the need for animals use to study things.<n><n>### Expanded Response 1: <n>This is the question in the first instruction. I don't know why we are given multiple choice since we have not been given any information about the locations.<n><n>### Exhibit E: This is the text that prompts us to the solution<n><n>### Explanations of Exhibit E: <n>This is a list of ways that we are given clues.<n><n>1. The first text suggests that monkeys are taken to research laboratories because they are often taken away from something. They could be taken away from the trees in the rain forest and to this place but we don't know which one of 6 options it is.<n><n>2. The second text narrows down the options because it suggests that there is a place where people wear white colored lab coats to treat of monkeys. We can eliminate choices A, B D, E.<n><n>3. However, there is choice C that says that monkeys are brought away from ___ to a __ which means that monkeys are taken away from one place and brought to another place and we can eliminate that choice too.<n><n>4. The third text gives us a way to narrow down the options because we we're told that the research laboratories focus on ___ that is medical and veterinary research. There are no other research laboratories and their purpose so we can eliminate choice B as well.<n><n>5. Finally, the option choice E can be eliminated because it is a location instead of an activity. This choice isn't correct<n><n>6. Now, we are only left with choices A or C.

How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:Where do people traditionally get information about the world? Choices:  A: book B: meeting C: television D: guide E: newspaper<n><n>### Response:		If you did not know which answer to choose, then select the most appropriate answer. Otherwise, select an answer and provide the reasons.<n><n>You have several options to choose from when looking for information about the world.  A: The first choice is a book. A book can provide a detailed and factual description of a topic. Books can also provide a different point of view than what is typically presented in the news. B: The second choice would be a meeting. Meetings are a chance to ask questions and discuss different perspectives on a topic. This is a good way to broaden your knowledge. C: The third choice is television. Television is a quick and reliable method of getting information about the world. However, it may cause you to only focus on one point of view. D: The fourth choice is a guidebook. Guidebooks give you the facts and figures of a place or time in history. They are useful for giving context to a place or topic. E: The last choice is a newspaper. Newspapers provide the facts of a topic, and they typically have their own point of view on the topic.<n><n>### Answer:  E<n><n>### Input<n>  Whenever she is going for a walk, Carla always keeps a tote bag in her backpack. She likes to be prepared wherever she goes. Do you agree with Carla’s decision to have a bag in her backpack?<n><n>### Response<n>I disagree with Carla's decision to always carry a bag in her back pack. It is not realistic to be carrying a tote bag when you walk somewhere. Sometimes it can be difficult to open your backpack and find the tote bag inside.  I think that it would be more practical to keep things handy so that they can be easily stored away when walking.<n><n>### Input : Which two teams had the exact same record last year?<n><n>A: Texas and Texas State<n><n>B: Texas A&M and Texas State<n><n>C: A&M-Corpus Christi and UTSA<n><n>D: Lamar and UTSA<n>E: Lamar and Texas A&M<n><n>### Response : <n><n>The two teams with the same record last year were Lamar and UT San Antonio. Give your students 30 minutes to complete their work and then have them return the assignment. The work done on the challenge can be assigned as homework or used during your next class when you would like to assess how each student is growing.  <n><n>### Challenge
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:Where is a road known as a motorway? Choices:  A: scotland B: europe C: race track D: new jersey E: england<n><n>### Response:		<n>**A**<n><n>### Instuctions:<n><n>Read the data below and answer the following questions.<n><n>* The first column contains the names of the people.<n>* The second column contains the number of miles the people have run this year.<n>* The third column contains the ages of the people.<n><n>1. How old is the oldest person who has run less than 3,200 miles?<n><n>### Demostration:<n><n>1. How many people run less than they did last year?<n>2. If age times the number of miles run this year gives a grand total of 11,400, what is the average age?<n>3. Who ran farther in 1998 than all but one other person - but not as far as two other people?<n>4. Who had the lowest number of miles and the highest age?<n><n>### Answer: <n>#### 1. 57 years old<n><n>#### 2. 7 people run less than the last year.<n><n>#### 3.  Tara<n><n>#### 4 Jack.

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:How might compassionate thoughful be described as being? Choices:  A: disengenious B: human C: weird D: kind E: stupid<n><n>### Response:		<n>Compassionate and thoughtful can only be described as "kind and human"<n><n>### Input How many hours of study does Shaniya need to ace her math final?<n>A. 50<n>B. A day<n>C. Two days<n>D. A week<n>    **_Response:_**<n>Shaniya needs to study 3.3333 hours a day to master her math final if she is to have it complete in one day.<n>### Input:The sum of a number and 10 less the number is 43 what is number<n>A. 18<n>B. 60<n>C. 73<n>D. 80<n>### Response :<n>The sum of a number an 10 less is 43 is given as 18 so the number is 44<n>### Input:What is the least common multiple of 60, 6?<n>A. 20<n>B. 6<n>C. 30<n>D. 105<n>### Response:The least common multiple of 160 and 6 can be found if you multiply 6 by every number from 1 to 11 and add 60, the answer is 600.<n>### Input : A train left Station A for Station B at 458PM. An hour later a commuter train left Station B for Station A. If the train from Station A is 70 percent as fast as the commuter train, what is the speed in miles per hour of the train from Station B?<n>A. 45<n>B. 46<n>C. 50<n>D. 55<n><n>### Response : The rate 70 percent as the commuter train means that the train from Station A went 70 percent as far as the commuter train in the same amount of time. The commuter train traveled 70 times as far as the commuting train, so the commuter train went 0.7 miles in 70 units to go 700 miles in 70 minutes. So at 450 per hour in miles per hour the the speed of the commuter train is 410.

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:What does one chop us a grape for? Choices:  A: fresh fruit B: wine press C: fruit basket D: fruit cocktail E: picnic basket<n><n>### Response:		<n>```<n>If two friends at a picnic have 4 and 3 juice boxes, who has the greatest number?<n>```<n><n>### Input 1:<n>What is three times the number of inches in a yard? Choices: A: 30 in. B: 36 in. C: 39 in. D: 42 in.<n><n>### Input2:<n>How many times does 3 go into 24? Choices: A. twice B. 9 times C. 3 times D. 4 times<n><n>### Response<n>```<n>Input 1: 36 inches in a yard.<n>Input 2: 9 times<n>```<n><n>## Explanation<n><n>`Input 1`<n><n>```text<n>Input 1:<n>What does one chop use a grape for?<n>A: fresh fruit<n>B: wine press<n>C: fruit basket<n>D: fruit cocktail<n>E: picnic basket<n>```<n><n>**Note:**The `Input 1` question is ambiguous because the words grape and one are both interchangeable with a person performing a task.<n><n>In this case, it is a chop performing the task of chopping or cutting a grape. For instance, one of the correct answers (choice D) says: "What does one chop a grape for?" or what does the chop do with the grape?<n><n>When `D = one` then `D = chop` and the choice is correct.<n><n>### Demo<n><n>For `Input 2`:<n><n>```python<n>a = Input<n>b = Choices<n>out = OutPut<n><n>print(b[1])<n><n>ans = a.solve(b,out)<n>print(ans)<n>```<n><n>```<n>In [1]:<n>What does one chope grape for?<n>C: fruit basket D: one chope grape for E: picnic basket B: wine press<n><n>Out[2]:<n>C: fruit basket <n><n>In [194]:<n>What is three times two times the number of inches  in a yard?<n>A: 30 in B: 36in	 C: 39	 D: 42	 E:24<n><n>Out[195]:<n>E:24<n><n>```

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:The friends loved competing against one another, it was a good way to work their what? Choices:  A: friendship B: aggression C: defeat D: winning or losing E: sweat<n><n>### Response:		The friends loved competiting against one another, it is a good way to work aggression.<n><n>### Input & Response:<n>The friends loved competing with one another, it was good way to work <n>their aggression.<n><n>```python<n>if(choice == "A"):<n>print("The friends loved competing agasint one another, it was an good way to work their aggression.") <n>elif(choice == "B"):<n>print("Sorry!")<n>elif(choice == "" or "c")://If there is no other than "B"<n>print("Sorry","Wrong")<n>else:<n>print("Sorry!, Please type a option")<n>```<n><n>### Input <n>The friend loved competiting with one another, it is an good way to work  their aggression.<n><n>

A) $<n>Answer:$5 x 28 = $140<n><n>Input: A group of 10 people traveled around the world in 82 days. If the 10 people traipsed at the same rate, how many days would each person have to travel around the world to move at the same rate as the group?<n>Answer: 8.65<n><n>### Input and Output<n>Input: There are 6 red stars in the sky, 5 yellow stars, and 2 blue stars. If the yellow stars add up to one-third the total amount of stars, how many stars are there?<n>Answer: $21$<n><n>### Solution:<n>Output: There are 21 stars in the sky. The yellow stars are $\frac {1}{3}$ the total number of stars. $1-\frac {1}{3}=\frac{2}{3}$. There are 6 red<n>stars in the sky. $6+\frac {2}{3}=\frac{16}{3}=\frac{5}{3}$. The yellow stars are half of half the total number of stars, which equals $\frac{1}{10}$ a fraction. Thus, there are 16 stars in the sky and 5 of them are yellow.<n><n>Output:
