Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:Before getting a divorce, what did the wife feel who was doing all the work? Choices:  A: harder B: anguish C: bitterness D: tears E: sadness<n><n>### Response:		B<n>### Explanation: In this case the wife is doing all the work so she feels anguish.<n><n>In this case the wife is working to help her husband she will feel bitterness.<n><n>### Inputs: The teacher asked 7 boys and 4 girls to find 3 more than the sum of the numbers on the chalkboard. The sum on the chalkboard was 42.How many chalkboard numbers were there initially?<n><n>### Response B<n>### Ex: The answer is 10 chalkboard numbers. When we see the boys and girls all total the same the number of chalkboard numbers is equal to the product of the boys and girls. We know that the product of boys and girls is 24 so if we add 42 to 24 we get 42 + 24 = 66 which tells us that we have 6 chalkboard numbers and not 10.<n>### Ex: What are two ways to describe 3 more than the number on the chalkboard? <n>### Choices: A: the number on the choolboard minus 3 B: 3 times as big C: 3 more than the value of the chalkboard <n><n>### Choice B is a way to solve this task, we need to find 3 larger.  <n>### It is the right answer<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>### Demo: We are going to the school dance tonight!<n>### If Daphne plans to stay for 15 minutes more than 20 minutes at the dance, and Janet expects to stay for x minutes less than half as long as Daphne expects to stay, how long are they expected to stay?<n><n>### Choices Choosing: 40 minutes 35 minutes 25 minutes<n><n>### This means  <n>### A: 40 minutes because 15+20 =45. 435 = 22 2+2=4 so 45+4= 50 total of 4 hours total which is 15 minutes longer than expected.<n><n>### B: 25 because 15 + 20 = 35. 10 + 35 = 45. 21+45 = 6

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:When eating everything on the tasting menu, what does one tend to feel? Choices:  A: full stomach B: getting full C: gaining weight D: sick E: satisfaction<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Instructions:<n>I'll give you 3 examples. You should be able to write your own.<n><n>1. Choose a number for each section of the example.<n>   1. What we say:<n><n>        > *The restaurant's tasting menu has 8 courses and is $120 for the 4 guests.*<n><n>    1. *What we mean:*<n><n>        > * The restaurant has 24 courses altogether, and each course costs $12.*<n><n>2. Choose a number that will tell us how many of something the restaurant has.<n>   1. Where we start:<n><n>        >*The soup is made from crab, squid, and bok choy.*<n><n>   2. The number of each thing you'll need:<n><n>        > 1. The soup has 747 of the ingredient crab. 2. It has  4460 of the ingredient squid.3. And it has  9642.5 of the ingredient bok.1.5<n><n><n>### Instructor's Comments:<n>**We can use words like,**<n><n>'The restaurant has 120 courses overall, and each course costs 20 dollars.'<n><n>'There are a total of 3987 crabs.'<n><n>**The point is we use what we know in the example and expand it using **,**and **the.**<n><n><n>'The crab has 9642.3 of the ingredient, bok choy. (A number multiplied by another number, then divided by the same number again).'<n><n>(Note: In order to use the "the" pronoun the number has to equal 1000).<n><n>**Here is another one:**<n><n>1. The restaurant has 125597 chairs and each chair costs 220$<n>The chairs have 310 of the material called "wood"<n><n>### Sample Examples:<n><n>### Response 1:<n><n>1. The number of things the restaurant has: 8 courses.<n>2. What the things are: 8 courses<n>3. Where the things start: $120<n>4. What the things cost:

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:Too many people want exotic snakes.  The demand is driving what to carry them? Choices:  A: ditch B: shop C: north america D: pet shops E: outdoors<n><n>### Response:		<n>```<n>  A)ditch<n>```<n><n>### Demand: <n>* too high= price rises<n>* too low= price decreases <n><n>### Different factors:<n>1- Influence<n>2- Population<n>3- Economy<n>4- Culture<n>5- Innovation<n><n>### Actions:<n>1- Subsidize farming<n>2- Restrict travel(tourism)<n>3- Restrict imports<n>4- Limit exports<n>5- Limit production through environmental regulations<n><n>### AI: <n>Human decision making model that can recognize complex patterns.<n><n>### AAA:<n><n>### Election:<n><n>In a national election in the United States, each state casts a number of electoral votes equal to its number of congressional representatives, plus two more votes if it is its own capital (i.e., the District of Columbia). Additionally, there are three more votes if the president is from the state, and one more vote for each U.S. Senator from the state (total of four).<n><n>The president is then elected according to a plurality of the popular vote (the candidate who receives the most votes wins), but each state has its own system for electing its electors.<n>

How many words are in Mark's sentence?<n><n>### Response:"Mark" is 5 letters long, "dog", "rosie", is 3 letters and "My name is" is 6 letters. So in total, the sentence has 14 words:<n><n>> "Mark" is 5 words.<n><n>"And" is 2 words.<n><n>"This" and "is" each have one word.<n><n>"My", "name", and "is" each has 3 words.<n><n>So in total, there are 14 words.<n><n>### Question:How many people are at least 10 feet tall?<n><n>### Answer:There are 7, including the 8-foot-tall woman and the boy.<n><n>### Example:The temperature in New York City was 90°F and 96°F in the shade. The boy says that it was not 100 °C.<n>> 40°F= 51°C<n><n>### Solution:It was 40°C in the shade.<n><n>### The temperature in London and Paris was 39°C on the same day. How far apart were the two cities?<n><n>### Solution:"If the temperature in London is 30°C, then the temperature in Paris is 69°C.<n><n>### Solution":The difference between London and Paris is 39°C - 30°C = 9°C<n><n>## Task:<n>Write a program or function that asks questions about input in this format. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:Where could a fungus grow and not be disturbed by sunlight? Choices:  A: under rocks B: manhattan C: toenails D: grocery store E: fallen tree<n><n>### Response:		<n>I think there are many choices where it can’t be harmed by sunshine and these are:<n><n>### Grocery store:<n>The grocery store is a dark place; it is also a place where there is not much sunlight. Therefore, a grocery store is one of places where a fungus can grow. I also thought that because it doesn’t have much sunshine, it can also not be disturbed by it.<n><n>### Fallen tree:<n>In my opinion, a fallen tree can become a home for fungus and not even be harmed by sunlight. It is because there is much sunlight at the top of a tree, but it’s much less at its base. The fungus would grow at the base of the tree, so that it doesn’t get exposed to sunrays. In addition, a tree’s roots are always in the dark, and the ground which contains mushrooms is moist, so it is perfect for fungus to grow.<n>

A mountain lion ate the cat and started the chase, which has gone on for 3 years now. However, she has caught a glimpse of the lion twice and now she is certain her cat is alive. If she has caught a glimse of the lion in 1 day, she has seen it at least. Choices:A: 2 timesB: 65 times C: 4 timesD: 25 timesE: 12 times<n><n>### Instructions:Answer:A: the correct answer is B, 65 times. When the woman catches a glimpse of her cat, that time she will have seen the mountain lion 65 times.<n><n>### Response<n>Response:The response has to be in the correct format. To determine the correct format<n><n>**Format** the correct answers are: Cats and Dogs and Pigs<n><n>**Structure** Cats = ____, Dogs = ____ and Pigs = ____.<n><n>The answer is in lowercase. The word that comes before the "And" is capitalized and the word that comes after the "and" is in lowercase.<n><n>**Content** cats and dogs are in the same amount and pig is lower of the three.<n><n>### Review<n>

Choices:  A: new jersey B: eastern united states C: good repair D: connecticut E: arizona<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/61477633/133883344-e330a880-a18c-4fd6-8204-42b61c7840a0.png)<n><n><n>### Input:"Several people are leaving on a bus. In all, there are 16 people. Everyone except 3 people has the same seat, and every seat is numbered. The woman's seat is number 12, and the bus driver has seat 15. What is the number of the seat between the bus driver's seat and the woman's seat?<n><n>### Response 15<n><n>### Response<n>![image](https//githubusercontent.com 133882834-acf25eb3-b28c-4af3-899f-89dcc1ef2d65.png)<n><n>### Explanation<n>The woman seat is 12, so the bus driver seat is 16, which is the next. So, the woman is missing seat 13, so the driver must be seat 15.<n>

Big house.<n>```<n><n>### Response<n><n>The correct answer is "living room."<n><n>### Explainer<n><n>The first line of the input is the instructions about what to ask. Choices: A. LIVING ROOM. B. DOG PARK..." That is the answer to the question and the choices in order. The question asks about a type of place, rather than a type of people, so the correct answer is “auditorium.” The most common names for gathering places for these kinds of religious speeches are “auditorium” and “synagogue.”<n>

Choices:  A: laugh B: sit C: being entertained D: math E: meet<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>B: sit <n>

How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:What would happen to a person if his or her money is stolen? Choices:  A: complete sentence B: feel angry C: drink tea D: cross street E: park<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>A  ->  A man would have difficulty paying rent or even putting food on the table. They would be homeless, without income or property, and it would be very hard to find work once they have recovered.<n><n>B  ->  A person would probably be angry.<n><n>C  ->  A person should drink tea.<n><n>D  ->  A person will go to park to take a rest.<n><n>E  ->  A person doesn't steal money itself.<n><n>### Input :When we finish, what do you wish to eat? Choices:  E: Pasta A: Stewed vegetable B: Spaghetti D: Cabbage salad C: Steamed rice F :Baked fish<n><n>### Responce:<n><n>E  -> Pasta<n><n>A  -> Stewed vegetable<n><n>B  -> Spaghetti<n><n>C  -> Steamed rice<n><n>F  -> Baked fish<n><n>## Input:What was the number of students enrolled at the university in each division last semester? Choices: A: Science and Technology B: Foreign Language A: Social Science C: Art D: Health and Wellness F: Humanities<n><n><n>### Respone: <n><n>A: Science and Technology<n>B: Foreign Language<n>C: Social Science<n>D: Art<n>F: Humanities

Choices : 1) A: tablet B: box C: notebook D: suitcase E: trunk<n><n>### Response & Solution : D & E<n><n>### InstRawS: What is a thin piece of wood or canvas on which oil paint is made? Choices : 2)A: picture B: baked good C: sheet D: banner E: sheet<n><n>### Response& Solution: E<n><n>### Write a word in the grid that will best complete the answer for each sentence. The answers for each sentence are shown below.<n><n>### A: How was it that you made such a ___ out of nothing?<n><n>### B: He didn't seem very ___ about the fact that he was going to be late for work.<n><n>### C: Don't play the piano if you don't already know how to ___.<n><n>### D:"How ___ you been?" asked Davey as he started the car.<n><n>### E: She seemed really ____ for the job interview.<n><n>### Solution A: made<n><n>### Solution B: happy<n><n>### Solution C: play<n><n>### Solution D: good<n><n>### Solution E: nervous<n><n>

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:He was a very sharp engineer, but when it came to the details his calculations could were often what? Choices:  A: complimentary B: inelegant C: ocean D: dull E: inaccurate<n><n>### Response:		B<n><n>### Explanation:The first sentence in the question gives you the answer options and clues. If his calculations were inaccurate he would do a calculation that would not be correct. This means he would calculate something that was wrong, and this means he would calculate something incorrect.<n><n>### Input. A cowboy herds cows. The cowboy herds seven cows. He decides to bring water to the cows. He uses a bucket to bring water. He uses two buckets to bring water. How many buckets of water did the cowboy bring to the cows?<n><n>### Response<n><n>16<n><n>### Explanaition<n><n>To calculate this you need to know the following:<n>-	A cowboy herds 7 cows<n>-	Each one uses 2 buckets<n>-	This means you have 14 buckets of water to get to the cows<n>

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:The person put on lotion, what did they want? Choices:  A: fresh smell B: good credit C: smooth skin D: fresh produce E: headache<n><n>### Response:		In the first choice of A, it means the person wants a fresh smell. In the second choice of B, it means the person has good credit. In the third choice of C, it means the person is looking for smooth skin. In the fourth choice of D, it means the person want fresh produce. In the fifth choice of E, it means the person have a headache.<n><n>### In the fourth choice of C, it's wrong because for person looking for smooth skin and in the fifth choice the person wants fresh produce.<n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:Mom is tidying a house, where would she put the loose dictionary? Choices:  A: shelf B: library C: classroom D: table E: desk<n><n>### Response:		<n>```shelf```<n><n>### Input A: In an apartment, Mary takes 12 days to complete 5 chores. She takes 7 days to finish 2 chores. How many days do all the chores take altogether to finish?<n>```26```<n><n>### Demo:<n>There are 12*1=12 days for finishing 5 chores. <n>There are 2*7=14 days for finishing 2 chores.<n>So the solution is 26 days. <n><n><n><n>### Input B: The price of a pair of shoes is 30 euros. The price of a tie is 20 euros. The cost of a shirt is 30 euro more than the price of a tie. How much does a whole outfit cost?<n>```91```<n><n>### Demos:<n><n>The cost of a shoe is 30 euors.<n>The cost of a tie is 10 euros.<n>The cost of the shirt is 20 euors more than the cost of the tie, which means the cost of the shirt 30 euors, So the cost of the whole outfit is 91 euros.<n><n>### Input C: There are 13 apples, 12 oranges, 8 bananas and 6 grapes stored in a basket. What is the total number of fruits in the basket?<n>```51```<n><n>## Input D:<n>There are 51 fruits<n><n>### Input E: Which of the following is the median number?<n>```5```<n>5, 2, 12<n>3, 5, 17<n>4, 10, 13<n>25, 71<n>64<n>89<n>5<n>```5```<n><n><n>There should be a number in the middle of a data set, so there are two groups of 5, 5+5==10. So the median number must be 5.<n><n># 듬옶스타<n>

Choices: Answer: 4<n><n>### Response<n>How many 1s am I thinking of then? Answer: 4<n>

How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:Jimmy wanted a beer but his wife was an alcoholic on probation.  Where might he go? Choices:  A: neighbor's house B: bridge C: home D: homeless shelter E: prison<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Input:{ "A": 2, "B": 5, "C": 2, "D": 1, "E": 1 } <n><n>### Response:{ name : 'Jimmy', answer : 5 }<n><n>### Input:[{ "name": "Pete", "age": 34 }, { "name": "Sarah", "age": 82 }]<n><n>### Response:[{ "name": 'Pete', "age": "34" }]<n><n>## Solution<n><n>```<n>let answer = 0;<n><n>const input = [<n>{ "name": 'Brenda', "age": '89' },<n>{ "name": "Mara", "age": '150' }<n>];<n><n>for(item of input){<n>   answer += item.age*2 + 9;<n>}<n><n>console.log(answer);<n><n>```

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:What happens when someone is playing too aggressively? Choices:  A: get hungry B: laughter C: injury D: having fun E: feeling happy<n><n>### Response:		<n>You laugh as your partner is injured and when you are in pain, you tend to laugh more. One of your muscles tenses and you feel tired, but instead all you think about is your next kill because you want to win, and this is not good.<n><n>### Actions:<n>* Have your partner check the map and position your tank so the flag is where the enemies would expect your tank to position itself.<n>* After you position your tank, keep your cannon pointed towards the enemy and shoot a few bullets.<n><n>### Rules<n>* If the enemy spotted you, you can get extra points, but if they are waiting for you to move, they will attack you aggressively.<n>* If they don’t attack you, they are likely positioning their tank, if you take out more tanks than the next tank in line, you will gain points, depending on how much damage you did and how many people died.<n>* If you are in the middle of a firefight, you will lose the round, but it is ok to wait a turn.<n><n>### Strategies:<n><n>* Keep your tank moving slowly so your teammates have time to react.<n>* Watch out for traps and keep your tank positioned as a surprise so the other team thinks your tank is going here and it has to travel further than necessary<n>* If you have a powerful teammate, always have your tank move out of their way so they can attack and you can recover points from the enemy, if the other team tries to trap you, the tank may be able to destroy one enemy tank, and you can also win with a team that has a powerful team member<n>* If the enemy tanks are close to death, they may run away from you and it can be hard to kill them, but if the enemy is dead, the flags can be won since no one wants to leave it to you<n>* Keep your tank away from the flag and position it so if the other team kills your tank, they would have to move closer to pick up the flag<n><n>### Problem: What will make me a more successful online gamer?<n><n>### Solutions<n>Use common sense when communicating to people that you do not know, so do not share personal information, and remember to stay on the safe side. Always avoid any people who ask for your location and personal information and use a nickname instead of your real

He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:A person with brown skin may share that skin with whom? Choices:  A: finger B: good health C: own family D: friends E: people<n><n>### Response:		<n>C<n><n>### Input<n>It seems that John has more books than Mary but Mary has one more book than Alice. How many books do John, Mary and Alice together have?<n><n>### Response<n>Mary has twice as many books as Alice. So, Mary and Alice have 6 books. Alice also has seven books so she has 13 books. And John has 13 books as well.<n><n>### Input The book club has 277 members. They want to evenly split the cost of the next book they read. How much does each member need to bring?<n><n>### Answer:<n>The cost of the next book is $59.80, so each member needs to bring $2.20.<n>(You can think of this problem as working with "decimals")<n><n>### Credits:<n>This assignment was originally created by David Liu. Revised by John Burk and Chris DeVenuto.<n><n>### Original Creator:<n>* [David Liu's blog](http://www.david-liu.org/2013/10/12/a-question-that-might-grow-you.html)<n>* [Email](dliu25@rice.edu)<n><n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:What happens to people playing games? Choices:  A: winning B: entertainment C: happiness D: cheating E: relaxation<n><n>### Response:		<n>My best guess is that A. <n><n>The people playing games have always 2 of the following options:<n><n>1. Winning, which makes them proud of themselves,<n><n>2. Entertainment which brings them fun and joy,<n><n>3. Happiness (even if they lose).<n><n>On the other hand, there are also 2 options which may happen:<n><n>1.  Cheating: this may happen only for the one who wants to win.<n><n>2.  Relaxation: this happens with the player, for not taking the games seriously and only as entertainment.<n>

How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:Where would one find a shopping bag for packing groceries? Choices:  A: supermarket B: home C: closet D: mart E: hardware store<n><n>### Response:		<n>Select Answer A. The shopping bag for packaging groceries could be found in the supermarket. The supermarket is a store that sells a lot of products and services like clothing, meat, cosmetics, etc. <n><n>### Input :<n>The difference between an hour and an hour-and-a-half.<n><n>### Response :<n>Select B, the difference is one-third of an hour. An hour has 60 minutes.<n><n>### Input<n>The average of 3 numbers. The average of the first and second numbers is 1 more than the average of the third and fourth numbers. If the average of the first three numbers is 8, then the third number is how much greater than the first number?<n><n>### Response<n>Choose B, the third number is 13. The third number is 11 because (18/7) + (18/8) = 2.5.<n><n>### Output<n><n>Answer : B<n><n>### Instructions<n>Input:The last number in a phone number consists of five zeros. The first two digits are 54.<n><n>Answer: The phone number is in this format: 545-0000. The extra 0000 part is an area code, so the full phone number is 545-5450.<n><n>### Additional Information<n>A phone number is a complex series of numbers and words that allow us to communicate by telephone. The following are the different parts of a phone number:<n><n>The area code is the first part of any telephone number. This shows the region the other numbers in a telephone number belong to. The first three digits of an area code indicate a metropolitan area. The last four digits of an area code are assigned by major telephone companies.<n><n>The exchange (abbreviated EXX) is the next section of a phone number. It shows the geographic location of a phone number.  The first three digits of the exchange are part of the area code, and the last four digits show the local office phone number.<n><n>The number is the last part of a telephone number. It consists of only the local telephone number. The number is in the format of 1 to 9 followed by two or three digits, a total of four to eight digits.<n><n>### Example

How much are all the coins?<n><n>### Request: How many different ways can you add 2 two-digit numbers? How many ways can you get a number such that the sum of its digits is 5?<n><n>### How many digits can be used in a 5-digit number formed from the digits 0, 1, and 2?<n><n>How many 4-digit numbers can be made from the digits 0 to 9 if the digit 0 is not used?<n><n>How many two-digit numbers are there?<n><n>How many different 5-digit telephone numbers can be formed if the last digit is always a 1?<n><n>How many triples of 3-digit numbers are there such that each has a different digit 0?<n><n>How many odd four digits numbers are there that end in the digit 5?<n><n>How many triplets of integers are there such that the sum of the first two is equal to the sum of the last two.How many even four-digit numbers are there that end with a 3?<n><n>How many integers are there such that square root of 2 is equal to the sum?<n><n>How many three-digit numbers are there so that both a digit and its reverse are used in the number?<n><n>How many unique combinations of a and b are there in the set {1, 2, 3, …, 7, 9, 11, 13, 15, 17, 19}?<n><n>How many single digit three-digit numbers are possible if the first number is even and the third number is odd?<n><n>What is the number of distinct triple of integers greater than 0 whose sum is odd?<n><n>### What is the smallest 4-digit Prime? He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:What happens when humans are exposed to noises? Choices:  A: pet the dog B: hear sounds C: have sex D: reproduce E: drive cars<n><n>### Response:		C. humans have sex<n><n>### Instructions:<n>In the text, we’ll find many instances of words that contain the letters _th_. Find the word in these sentences that could be used to form the plural of _them_.<n>* They went to that restaurant.<n>* They don’t think so.<n>* The kids made snowmen.<n>* The dog ate that food.<n>* The teacher saw the boy.<n>* They have a good time!<n><n>### Input<n><n>Find the word in these sentences<n><n>* They went to their restaurant.<n>* They were on my team.<n>* They don't think so.<n><n>**_them_ is the word  <n>_th_ _em_ _s_ <n><n>* These students are all my friends.<n>* These students don't follow the rules.<n>* They should all stay in school.<n>* These students are always happy.<n>* They are not scared of anything.<n>* They don&quot;t need to eat anymore.<n>* These students have been playing since 1993.<n>### Input:<n>In the texts we analyze in class, I'll find more references to _th_ words than are in this classroom. Find all that are in this classroom and then write in the plural.<n>* They went to the restaurant.<n>* They didn't think so.    <n>* The kids built their snowmen.<n>* He ate his food?<n>1. Who's your teacher?<n><n>### Instruct:<n>Write your letter response addressing the following to Ms. Miller<n><n>- Thank you for the email<n>- I will start studying soon<n>	- I will begin by reviewing the notes from the reading for Monday.<n>	- I promise to complete three pages a day.<n>Hope you are well. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:James's bouncing rubber balls were at rest, and so he could sleep.  He would get up in the morning, and then put them in what state again? Choices:  A: upside down B: in motion C: active D: wakefulness E: resthold<n><n>### Response:		The question says that the balls were at rest initially. Then, they will be in motion when James got up in the morning.So the answer is B.<n><n>### Input:"It's the same thing, no matter where you go, there you are" is a famous quo: It's what, and what kind of thing?<n><n>### Response:"It's the samething, no matter where you are, you are you". The quo is a saying and it is a famous saying.<n><n>### Solution: You can see that it is a one-way task. There is no need to read the question and instruction carefully.<n><n>### TF:What two things do we need for the solution?<n><n>### TA:We need 2 things for the solution. An instruction and a question.<n><n>## Part 2<n>---<n>Now let’s see how to understand a task with multi-choice questions.<n><n>First, you have to read the question carefully. If you do not read the question carefully, you might answer a wrong question.<n><n>Let’s see a famous sayin:It's the same things everywhere you go, there you'll be.<n><n>##### Solution A:<n><n>* You can see that it's a multi-choice question.<n>* We need to read this quo carefully and then we can get a suitable choice.<n><n>#####  Solution B:<n>If you find that there is no "there", you must say “You are you”. Then, your answer must not pass the test.<n><n>---<n><n>If you are asked a question:“A piece of cake is 50% larger than what? what? ”.<n><n>Then, you can see that the answer choices are c,d,a,b,e.<n><n>Now, you find b as the answer of the question, but it does not match the question.So you will not be able to pass the test.<n>

The question suggests that, until then, I was comfortable, but fearful of doing so.

Week after Christmas " Week is a part of time<n><n>### Notes :<n>- The next questions will be a lot harder so be ready<n>- This type of analysis would be best done in a language other than your language of instruction. <n>- Analyzing text oral or written, this is the type of skill required in any language class.<n>- You are being taught to analyze any language, not just English, as the skill is so useful.<n><n>### Directions:<n>Answer five words at a time - just type

She was doing her best and she wanted to sleep but she would not because she needed to convince the audience. The speaker did her best because she wanted to put money in the box.<n>

How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:What did the business require of everyone walking into their store? E: do well<n><n>### Response:		<n>Choices:<n>A: wear shoes<n>B: learn<n>C: hope for peace<n>D: have a great day<n>E: do well<n><n>The following is a multi-step task.<n><n>### Task:<n><n>Input: On a survey, most people said they wanted peace on Earth. Some people don't, though! Write a sentence that shows that having peace on Earth would be good.<n><n>### Your Answer:<n><n>Peace on earth is what everyone wants. With peace on earth, there will be no more war and killings on earth.<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:The sun was out and the temperature changing rapidly, it was really beginning to what? Choices:  A: drop to zero B: increase C: cool down D: dropping quickly E: heat up<n><n>### Response:		It was cooling down<n><n>### Instructions:In this task, you work  a program that uses the concept of nested for loops.<n><n>### Note:<n>-A for loop loops continuously over a specified range of numbers.<n>The body of the for loop is executed when the loop counter reaches a defined limit.<n>The loop counter increases when the body finishes executing.<n>When a value for the loop counter reaches the end of the given range, the loop<n>counter resumes at 0.<n>The test that follows the loop counter’s value determines whether or not to enter the next loop.<n>-A for loop statement consists of the for keyword followed by three expressions<n>as specified in the following example.[^3]:<n>[#3]:[^3]: https://www.ibm.com/developerworks/community/wikis/home?lang=en#!/wiki/Rapid/page/Lesson%3A+The%20for%20statement<n>```<n>for (<loop-counter-name>=<initial-value>; <test>; <increase>, <decrease>){<n>	<statement>;<n>}<n>```<n><n>### Note<n>-A nested loop is a loop inside a loop. It is created by placing another for loop inside an outer for loop.<n>-The outer for loop is the upper loop.<n>-The inner for loop is the nested loop. It’s the lower loop.<n><n>### Response<n>```<n>for (a=2; a <= 14; a++){<n>	for (b=1; b <= 5; b++){<n>		print(a, “ = “, b)<n>	}<n>	print()<n>}<n>```<n>The body of the outer loop contains one line that defines the test (the upper bound on the loop counter) and the body of the inner loop. The nested loop will print all possible combinations of the numbers in its range to the output window.<n><n>When the outer loop is first entered, it prints the numbers 2 through 5 to the output window. Then it loops back to the outer loop to continue.<n><n>### Input<n>We have a string and a pattern.We want to find out how many times a string contains the pattern.<n><n>### response<n>```<n>for (pattern in string)<n>	if (pattern == pattern)<n>		if (

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:What would form on your feet, if you were jogging all day? Choices:  A: heart attacks B: hole in your socks C: exhaustion D: shortness of breath E: blisters<n><n>### Response:		1<n><n>### Answer (solution):<n><n>### Coding:<n>Code.py:<n><n>```python<n>from math import ceil<n><n>def multiple_of_ten(n, denom):<n>    return int((n - (n % denom)) / denom)<n><n><n>def main():<n>    answer = multiple_of_ten((175 - (175 % 10)) / 10, 10)<n>    answer = ceil(answer)<n>    print(answer)<n>```<n><n>```python<n><n>```<n>

How many more students use their tablets than paper?<n>### Answer Choice A: 17<n><n>#### Instructions<n>This is an addition sequence question. Write an answer that appropriately completes it.<n><n>#### Demonstration<n>Choose the answer that fits best.<n><n>10 + 15 = _<n><n>What are the next 2 numbers in sequence? Write them in the boxes below. Answers: 1 _ and 1 _<n><n>### What does $24.67 x 22 look like when it is written out in words?<n>### Answer 2693 dollars, 67 cents<n><n>#### Instruitions<n><n>This is a multiplication sequence question. Choose 2 numbers, add the digits (10 + 10), and then multiply that by the last number. That is how you get the next number. Write an answer that matches the sequence.<n><n>

Since a lot was also wild, it only made sense as what was next.<n><n>### Discussion: <n>The answer is correct, but there are better ways to solve this problem. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:His day at the office was nearing an end, he went to the start menu on his computer to do what? Choices:  A: run programs B: play games C: control model D: power down E: reason exists<n><n>### Response:		**A)**<n><n>### Instructor feedback<n><n>You can add some comments and explanation about the solution here.<n><n>```java<n> // 1st solution<n> int n1 = Integer.parseInt(br.readLine());<n> int n2 = Integer.parseInt(nextWord);<n> int n3 = Integer.parseInt(lastWord);<n> <n> int c1 = n1 - n2;<n> <n> if (n3!= c1) {<n>	 System.out.println("Incorrect");<n>	 return;<n> }<n> <n> System.out.println(c1);<n><n> // 2nd soln<n> int n = Integer.parseInt(input);<n> int a1 = n % 5 == 0;<n> String firstStr = a1? "even" : "odd";<n> int a2 = n % 2 == 0;<n> if (a1 && a2) {<n> 	System.out.println("it is divisible by 4 and even");<n>	System.out.print("\ni.e.: ");<n>	System.out 	.print(n);<n>	return;<n> }else if(a1 &&!a2) {<n>	System.out	.println("\ti.e.: ");<n>System.out.print(n);// it is not dividable by 4 and odd<n> }else if(! a1 && a2)	{<n>   System.out.println("\ti. e.: ");<n> 	System. out.print(n); // not dividable by 2 or even<n>}else{<n>	 System.out			.print("\ni.t.e.: ");<n> System.out.print( n ); // not dividable by either 4 or 2<n>}<n>```<n><n> <n>

For example, if a collection consisted of two numbers (6 and 8) the mean would be 7. If a collection had 3 values (2, 3, 5) the mean would be (2+3+5)/3 = 4<n>Write a data structure (an data type or data-structure that is written in C++ that can calculate and return the average of a collection of items.<n><n>Instrucitons: Write a program that allows the user to determine the average and standard deviation of a list of numbers.<n><n>### Expected Output:<n>* User is prompted to enter in a number of data.<n>* In the end the program should print the average, lower limit, upper limit, and standard deviation of the data entered.<n><n>Instrucsitons: The data entered is expected to be a list of integers<n><n>### Expectant Output:<n><n>### Explanation: To perform the required calculations the provided program should:<n><n>* calculate the data entered for average and standard deviation of the list entered. <n><n>	* Note that the program should output 2 values for the average and 2 values for the standard deviation (the upper limit for the standard deviation should also be a number).<n><n><n>### Exprectation for standard deviation<n>* calculate the standard deviation<n><n>	* Note

Some scored 80 or above. All those students who scored below 80 counted as failures. The class of 37 scored as failures. What percentage of the class got at least 80? (Answer choices: 352%, 390%, 434%, 444%<n>###Response<n>```python<n>#if else<n>if sum((x>80 for x in list(range(66))) > 37:<n>    percent = 0<n>else:<n>    percent = (sum(x<80 for x in range(66))/ float(66)*100)<n>print(percent)<n>```<n>

How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:John couldn't find a place to stay, and he didn't want to waste money.  He picked a place that was inexpensive and offered few luxuries.  Where might he be staying? Choices:  A: farm B: town C: city D: hotel E: motel<n><n>### Response:		Five miles from the farm is a town, but it is only two miles from the city. The motel is halfway between town and city.<n><n>### Explanation:The answer will probably be an inexpensive hotel. An inexpensive, unluxurious place to stay would be a hotel and a motel. A motel is between a farm and a town. The only two places between a town and a city is a farm and a hotel. It is 10 miles from the farm to the town and 5 miles from the town to the city. The town might be 2 miles from a motel.<n><n>### Input:[(Mike's sister) and Mike] all like math. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:Traders work on the floor of the stock what? Choices:  A: building B: hallway C: table D: exchange E: office<n><n>### Response:		The traders work on the floor of The Stock Exchange.<n><n>### Input : What is the length of the line AB?<n>A:  12 inches B:  11 inches C:  13 inches D:  10 inches<n><n>### Response : The length of the line AB is  12 inches.<n><n>### Question: How many pounds of apples did Lily sell if she made 28 times as much as she did yesterday?<n>A:  59 pounds B:  41 pounds C:  16 pounds D: 195 pounds<n>### Response : Answer: 195<n><n>### Instructions Write a number to indicate the choice that best completes the statement or answer the question. Choices: A: zero B: positive integer<n><n>### Instuctions: How many times does the sign +13 appear in the expression 4 + 9 - 8 + 5 - (3 + 5)?<n>### Response : <n>### Instrucor: What is the weight in kilograms of 6.5 pounds?<n><n>### Answer: 3.250<n><n>### Instructor:What is the weight of 8 kilograms in pounds?<n><n>###### Response:<n>### Instruction : Select the letter A to 13 or B if none of the above.<n>### The answer is 0 because none of the above is true.<n><n>### The answer will be between three to eight because this is the range or value.<n><n>## Instructions: Write one space for each number. In your program, read the input as integers from the user. Use a while loop to read input until the user has input a -1. When the user has input -1, end the program.<n>* The output should be the sum of the integers plus the number of digits in the numbers.<n><n>| Input | Output |<n>| :--- | :--- |<n>| 1 2 -1 | 3 3<n><n>| Input |Output |<n>| :---:| :---:|<n>| -2 9 -1 | -2 1 |<n><n>| Input | |<n>| :---|:---|<n>| -3 -2 -1 | 0 |<n><n>Example of a working program(s) is provided in the project folder.<n><n><n>### **Program Details:**<n><n>You must complete the following tasks<n><n>1. Read positive integer, the number of digits of the numbers, and a negative integer.<n>1. Call the `processList()` function.<n>   1. In the processList() function, read the positive integer from the input array.<n>   1. Output "the digit of the last number (in the list)", and multiply it by the number of digits in each number.<n>   1. Add all the values up.<n>   1. At the end of program, print an output of the total.<n><n>### **Rules:**<n><n>* You do not need to write the code using a for loop.<n>* You do not have to print out the digits.<n><n>### Part I: **Floating Numbers**<n><n>**1.** Read floating point numbers.<n><n>**2.** Call the `processListFloating()` function.<n><n><n>In the `processListFilling()` function,<n><n>1. In the last item, read a positive and negative integer (from the same element).<n>2. Add the two numbers and let the result (not the sum) be the "digit of the last number".<n>3. In the last number, multiply that result by the number of digits of each number in the list.<n>4. Add that whole value of all the items.<n>5. Now

How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:The explorers found a central passage, much to their delight it led straight to the ancient buried what? Choices:  A: public building B: tomb C: arena D: large building E: treasure<n><n>### Response:		What we learned about the Central Passage was that it led straight to the tomb of the ancient Pharaoh.<n><n># Write the following tasks as if instructing the other person how to complete the task.<n><n>### Input<n>Dexter has six times as many postage stamps as Brenda. Brenda has 14 fewer stamps than Harry. How many stamps do they all have in all?<n>A: Harry has 9 stamps fewer than the others, so the others have a total of 92.<n><n>### Output<n>They each have 68 postage stamps.<n><n>### Demo<n><n>Input: Sarah is 3 times as old her sister. Her son is 1 year younger than 3 times her son's age. How old are they?<n>Answer: Sarah is  23 and her son is 2<n><n>Input: A farmer sowed 240 bushels of wheat, 40 bushels of peas, 140 bushels of barley, and 30 pecks of peas. If he harvested half of the wheat, two-thirds of the barley, and one-fifth of the peas, how many bushels of each grain were harvested? <n>Answer: 120 bushels of wheats, 28 bushels of peas and 80 bushels of barleys<n><n>### Instructions: <n><n>### Demo:<n>Input: John is not as good at math as his brother Bill. Bill solved as many math problems as a student at the same grade level had wrong. Bill then solved as many math problems in a shorter amount of time as his brother solved correctly. Who has the better math skills?<n>Answer:Bill has better math skills.<n><n><n>### Instuction:<n><n>### Demo/Demonstration:<n>Input : The cereal aisle at the store has 24 boxes of cereal. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. How much row does the teacher’s pet sit in?<n><n>### I think : Answer : Row 3.<n><n><n><n>## Instruction: A lady has a 95% chance of winning and a 75% chance of losing. If she makes the bet, what are her chances that she will win the bet?<n><n>### 68.5%<n><n>### Why: 0.95^2 + 0.75^2 = 1.6625.<n><n>### Divide by 2 to remove square roots: 0.83125 = 83.125%<n><n>## Instruction.<n><n>### Input<n><n>### Input Input: How old are 5 children with a mean of 45 and a median of 40?<n><n># How Old Are 5 Children with a Mean of 45 and A Median of 40? ##<n>The mean is average. 1.36%<n><n>### Response<n><n>### Input How many students are enrolled in a classroom with an average of five

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>### Input:The man set the cup on the table.  It didn't matter.   He didn't heave anything to put it on, and he lacked the what to balance it? Choices:  A: tenacity B: hands C: coaster D: skill E: breaking<n><n>### Response:		<n>If the man had the required things to balance it, there would be no need for anything to be put on the table.<n><n>### Input<n>Maria had 19 apples. She gave one to her brother and one to each of the children that were sitting around her.  How many apples did she have left?<n><n>### Response<n>If Maria had a lot of apples, there would be no reason to "give one to her brother and each of the children" that may be seated around her. It would be enough for her just to give them to all the children or for her to give them to her brother.<n><n>### Note:<n>If you get stuck, you can take out your calculator and do some math. Then, use your calculator to test your answer. Be sure to always show your work.<n><n>### Hint<n><n>Use the *number line* to help you.<n><n>On a number line, the numbers always go from left to right. If you are looking for a number, you start at the left and go towards the right. If you divide by a number, don't assume you go left, for it won't matter either way you move.<n><n>Try to find the answer using only arithmetic, since we'll also use arithmetic to check if and explain an answer.<n><n>### Example:<n><n>Input: Maria had 19 appels. She gave one to ber older brother and one to each child that was sitting around meme. How many f appels did she have i left?<n>Answer:17<n><n>### Input, 4.5 gallon of coffee were divided among eighteen thermos. Genevive drank three thermos. How many pint of coffee did Genevive drink.<n><n>### Response, If she had the required gallons to drink, there would be no requirement to "drink three thermos".<n><n>### Example<n><n>Input: Genevieve drank one third 3 of the thermoses. How many gallons of coffee did she drink?<n>Answer:0.5 gallons<n><n>### Input.<n>I saw an ant climb up, across, back to the grass.<n><n>### 1. How many trips did he make over?<n><n>Ans.:3, if he traveled the first leg (up) on the way back.<n><n>
